moves.1. d4: I approached this game carefully. My opponent was only 11 years old, and I was mindful of how I lost once to a Chester youngster with a similar age and a similar grade. https://gameknot.com/annotation.pl/chester7vpenyffordd2wirral-league?gm=49458
moves.1... d5: So he copies my first move.
moves.5... h6: he puts the question to my bishop.
moves.6... Ne4: He plays the Lasker variation... known to be a bit drawish. https://www.chess.com/article/view/lasker-s-queen-s-gambit-declined
moves.8... dxe4: He takes back - and the question is how to continue? I can see now in the opening databases that Ne2 is usually played here, but I was a bit afraid of the queen check on b4 and decided to stop it.
moves.10. Ne2: Now the knight comes out. Fritz thinks it is level.
moves.10... Rd8: A fairly logical place to put the rook.
moves.11. Nc3: I attack the pawn on e4 and prepare tp develop Bf1.
moves.11... Nc6: But what is this? Just gifting the pawn on e4?
moves.12... b6: He prepares to fianchetto his Bc8.
moves.13. Bd3: I develop mine, protecting the Ne4.
moves.14... Rd7: Preparing to double rooks on the d file.
moves.15. a3: Ruling out his knight or queen coming to b4 and also preparing to grab territory on the queen side.
moves.15... Na5: Hoping for a knight fork on b3.
moves.16... Rad8: He completes his doubling manoeuvre on the d file.
moves.17... Nc6: Knight drops back. Fritz outs white as plus .97 now.
moves.18. f3: This seemed sensible at the time, giving more protection to my Ne4, but I soon realised it is a mistake. He could now cause problems with 18......f7-f5, forcing my knight away and then continue with 19....f5-f4 undermining my pawn on d4 which is holding everything together.
moves.18... Nb8: Fritz agrees with me - f5 followed by f4 and white's advantage is down to plus 0.81 This move seems far too passive. I think his plan was c7-c5
moves.19. b5: Which I decide to stop. I am planning on meeting c7-c5 with bxc6 e.p.
moves.19... a6: He tries to lure my pawn away.
moves.20. a4: But I simply protect it. Fritz prefers f3-f4 here.
moves.20... c6: He attacks b5 again, but this leaves his pawn on b6 very weak. I was rather afraid of him playing c6-c5 next move, hence my reply.
moves.22. Rab1: I attack b6. Fritz likes this too.
moves.22... f5: But now this move comes in at last.
moves.23. Ng3: I play this with the idea of meeting 23,,,,,f5-f4 with 24. exf4 Nxd4 25. Be4 and my Ng3 keeps the e2 square under control, stopping a nasty knight fork on that square. Fritz prefers 23. Nf2.
moves.23... Ne5: An ingenious move, if I take the knight on e5 then my bishop on d3 goes to his rook and the advantage has passed to black. Fortunately I don't have to take it.
moves.24. Bc2: Fritz agrees that this is the best move, and give the position as plus 2 to white now.
moves.24... Nc6: He sees nothing better than retreating the knight.
moves.25. Ne2: Now if he plays f5-f4 I simply take with the knight. There is no rush to take the b pawn, it can't escape.
moves.26... Rd7d6: He challenges the rook. Fritz also now likes 27. a5 protecting the rook, with plus 3 to white, but I do something else.
moves.28. Rxb6: I take back, planning on meeting Rd6 with Qb4.
moves.29. Rxe6: But this goes. Plus 3.75 to white now.
moves.29... Rc8: With the threat of Qxc4 but I am ready for it.
moves.30. Bxf5: Now 30....Qxc4 can be met with 31. Re8+ or with exchanging queens and then playing Re8+. In either case white has a winning advantage.
moves.30... Qf7: So his queen hurries over to protect his king-side
moves.31... Rf8: His rook comes over to attack my bishop again.
moves.33. Nf4: Protecting my rook and threatening a horrible check on g6. Plus 7.41 to white now, according to Fritz.
moves.33... g5: He gives his king some space. Fritz now likes Rxh6
moves.34... Kxh7: He takes the bishop. Fritz is now crying out for Ne7+ but again I go along another path.
moves.35. Re7: I decide to win his queen.
moves.35... Qxe7: This leads to his mate. Fritz thinks that Kg8 was best, but still gives it as almost plus 9 to white.
moves.38. Qxh6#: And is now mated. Thanks for reading. Please let me know how I am getting on with stars and/or a few comments. Until next time dear reader!

players: Charles L Higgie (ECF174) vs. Sam Birchett (ECF86)
